text: Creates a volume filled with volumetric clouds.
This node can create a volume filled with clouds generated from noise.
You can also connect in a
volume, and the Sky Box will generate 3D clouds from it. Various parameters have a pop-up menu controlling how the parameter is set. The default,
, uses the Sky Box’s parameter values. You can change this to
to use the related parameter from the connected Sky Field node. See
for how to use the Sky Box node with Sky Fields.
When you connect a volume to this node’s first input, this is the name of the source volume for the skybox. You can connect multiple Sky Box nodes in sequence to combine multiple cloud types.

to this node’s second input, this is the name of the volume to use as the source of the cloud pattern. If you don’t connect the second input, this node generates cloud-like noise itself. The Sky Field node has parameters, such as
, that influence how Sky Box generates the 3D clouds.
If you connect geometry to the third input, this node uses its bounding box as the size of the sky box. You can turn this on or off using the
tab. If the third input is not connected, or
is off, the node uses the
is wired into the node’s second input, this blends between the original input and the Sky Field. If you set the popup menu to
, this slider is disabled and the node uses the Sky Field node’s mask. If you set the popup menu to
, this slider multiplies the value in the
The size of a voxel in the Pyro simulation.  Cutting your voxel size in half will require eight times the memory and time, so a careful trade off between detail and pragmatism is required.
Random seed for this node’s noise. Changing this number generates different cloud patterns.

Controls how much of the sky is obscured by clouds. Lower values will create smaller cloud patches with lesser density separated by larger spaces, while large values will create one continuous denser, large cloud volume.
is wired into this node’s second input, change the menu on the right side of this parameter from
to overwrite the value of the parameter using the Sky Field.
Additional control over how much of the sky is obscured by clouds.
is wired into this node’s second input, change the menu on the right side of this parameter from
to overwrite the value of the parameter using the Sky Field.
Controls how much the cloud spreads out at the top of the cloud.
is wired into this node’s second input, change the menu on the right side of this parameter from
to overwrite the value of the parameter using the Sky Field.
Controls how to shade the volume. When generating cloud patterns, use
to see all the finer details and
to display clouds in a more realistic manner.
Uses ambient shadowing to display the volume.
Reverses the ambient shadowing for volumes which can be used to give a more realistic cloud look with internal scattering.

Fixed multiplier on the density field to control how opaque the volume is.
    If you are using a larger scene scale, you may need a smaller density scale.

Fog density is density per unit length, and is independent of the 
        resolution. So the same sized box, at 100 or 10 divisions, should be the
        same opacity. This means very small boxes will become transparent,
        especially if HDR rendering isn’t on. You can enable HDR rendering on
        the

format to at least 16-bit for 3D textures
        can also help resolve low-density volumes. These settings can be found
        under the
Determines the intensity of self shadows from ambient light sources. The final amount of self-shadowing from these lights is controlled by the product of
. The video demonstrates the value increasing from 0 to 1.
Turning off this checkbox does not disable ambient shadowing. Instead, it keeps this property of the geometry unchanged. If no
controls the default amount of self-shadowing from ambient lights.
The default headlight is treated as an ambient source by fog volumes.

Color of smoke that’s receiving direct light from an ambient light source.
    The default white setting indicates that areas exposed to external lights
    are bright. You can set this darker than

to achieve a
    more cloud-like look, where areas deeper within the cloud experience more
    light scattering and thus appear brighter.

must be
    enabled to control this parameter.

Color of smoke that’s not receiving any light from an ambient light source.
    The default black setting indicates that areas occluded from light are dark.
    You can set this brighter than

to achieve a more
    cloud-like appearance, where areas deeper within the cloud (that is, those
    occluded from outside light) are more luminous due to a greater degree of
    internal scattering.

must be enabled to control this
    parameter.
Controls the overall size of the sky region that is filled with clouds.
Controls the overall position of the sky region that is filled with clouds.
When this is on and geometry is connected to the third input, this node uses the bounding box of the third input instead of the
parameters. Turn this off to ignore anything connected to the third input and use
Use the convex hull of the points for activation.
The position on the Y-axis where the bottom of the cloud sits. Increase the number to position to cloud higher up in the atmosphere. Make sure this altitude falls into the bounding box given by
is wired into this node’s second input, change the menu on the right side of this parameter from
to overwrite the value of the parameter using the Sky Field.

The vertical extent of the cloud. Smaller wispy clouds might require a thin layer, while large billowy clouds usually need a larger thickness. Make sure this altitude falls into the bounding box given by
is wired into this node’s second input, change the menu on the right side of this parameter from
to overwrite the value of the parameter using the Sky Field.
Allows vertical deformation of the generated sky to create a sky dome. This is useful in shifting distant clouds to meet horizon lines.
Sets the position on the Y-axis where the bottom of the sky dome sits.
The radius of the sky dome. Increase this value to create a larger sky dome.
Controls the center position of the sky dome. Use this control when the sky dome is not located at the origin.
This ramps controls the curvature of the sky dome based on the distance from the center of the sky dome.

When you convert a Sky Field (connected to the second input) to 3D clouds, the results might be visually displeasing. You can try turning on this option, which adds noise to the sampling points across the 3D Sky Box.
is on, this is the strength of the noise used to vary the sampling position. Larger values create more broken-up shapes, but also could distort the look of the Sky Field.
Uniform scale of elements in the noise.
Offset within the evaluated noise field (added to each axis). If you have the general noise effect you want but want to get a different set of values for a different look, try changing the offset.
The scale increment between iterations of fractal noise added to the basic output. The higher the value the larger the
added to the output. You can use a negative value for roughness.
Scales the falloff from cloud to emptiness at the
of the cloud, from 0 to 1 relative to the
of the Sky Box. Raising the first number gives the top of the clouds more density before they fall off. Lowering the second number makes the density at the top of the clouds fall off faster.
is wired into this node’s second input, change the menu on the right side of this parameter from
to overwrite the value of the parameter using the Sky Field.
Controls how flat the top of the clouds should appear.
Scales the falloff from cloud to emptiness at the
of the cloud, from 0 to 1 relative to the
of the Sky Box. Raising the first number gives the bottom of the clouds more density before they fall off. Lowering the second number makes the density at the bottom of the clouds fall off faster.
is wired into this node’s second input, change the menu on the right side of this parameter from
to overwrite the value of the parameter using the Sky Field.
Controls how flat the bottom of the clouds should appear.
Raises the vertical thickness of the cloud relative to its given thickness (given by

).
    If the thickness is set to
, the overall vertical thickness of the cloud will be
is wired into this node’s second input, change the menu on the right side of this parameter from
to overwrite the value of the parameter using the Sky Field.

The generated sky region is always clipped according to the given bounds. When the skybox is large enough, this clipping might not be visible. However, when only a small patch of clouds is needed, turn on this control to create a much more natural boundary based on a spacial noise. The boundary is always eroded in an oval shape.
Controls how much cloud area erodes away from the boundary. Larger values will leave a smaller sky region with clouds, but their boundary will be more broken up.
Uniform scale of elements in the spacial noise that is used for erosion.
Offset within the evaluated noise field (added to each axis). If you have the general noise effect you want, but want to get a different set of values for a different look, try changing the offset.
This value expands or shrinks the overall range of tonal values. Particularly, each noise value is pushed towards (if
When this is turned on, sizes and positions the voxels of the VDB based on the frustum of a
The path to the camera object to align the VDB to. For example,
The distance, in Houdini units, from the camera to the near side of the frustum used to calculate voxel size.
The distance, in Houdini units, from the camera to the far side of the frustum used to calculate voxel size.
The default noise generated inside the sky box to create billowy cumulus cloud like shapes.
The type of noise to generate. Different algorithms give noise with different characteristics.
Generates a perlin noise-based cloud pattern influenced by the
Generates a simplex noise-based cloud pattern influenced by the
parameter. Simple noise is similar to Perlin, but the noise lattice is on a tetrahedral mesh rather than a grid.  This can avoid the grid patterns often visible in Perlin noise.
Generates a fast simplex noise-based cloud pattern influenced by the
parameter. This simplex noise function uses a different lattice structure and a cheaper accumulation method.
Uniform scale of elements in the noise.
Per Component button for separate scales along each axis.
Per Component button, this lets you scale the
Offset within the evaluated noise field (added to each axis). If you have the general noise effect you want, but want to get a different set of values for a different look, try changing the offset.
You can animate the noise using an expression such as
here. This is faster to compute than
, but gives the visual effect of
across the noise field, which may or may not be acceptable.
Per Component button for separate additional offsets along each axis.
Per Component button, this lets you add the a separate offset along each axis.
When turned on, a worley noise is combined with the noise pattern (specified by

) to give puffy cloud noise.
    Enabling this, will largely diminish the distortion effect (specified by
Noise pattern with added worley noise:
Controls the amount of mixing between the noise pattern (specified by
) and the worley noise. A value of
means no worley noise is applied to the noise pattern.
Controls how fast the edges of the noise pattern turn to zero. The larger the value, the more the edges are eroded creating smaller and smaller cloud patches.
parameter that effects the worley noise pattern.
Controls the overall gamma of the generated noise. Values less than

will darken the noise, increasing the range of values in originally bright areas.
    Conversely, values greater than
will stretch out the range of values for originally dark areas, which will increase the overall brightness of the noise.
This value expands or shrinks the overall range of tonal values. Particularly, each noise value is pushed towards (if
The number of iterations of distortion to add to the output of the basic noise. The more iterations you add, the more

the output. Note that the output may have fewer octaves than this parameter (that is, increasing the parameter will eventually stop adding detail), because the node eventually stops when there’s no more room to add more detail in the output.
The frequency increment between iterations of fractal noise added to the basic output. Note that you can use a negative value.
The scale increment between iterations of fractal noise added to the basic output. The higher the value the larger the
added to the output. You can use a negative value for roughness.
Controls how much the noise is distorted in the direction of decreasing noise values if
, and in the direction of increasing noise values if
. When worley details are added to the noise pattern, the effect of distortion are largely diminished.
How much to stretch the noise in each direction. The advantage of using this instead of
is that it preserves some details unstretched, making the stretched noise pattern more natural looking.
Warps the generated noise such that the noise pattern is bending or hanging towards the given droop direction.
Noise pattern without (left) and with droop applied (right):
The direction in which the noise is warped.
Applies an additional alligator noise to the default billowy noise generated inside the Sky Box to create billowy cumulus cloud like shapes.
Generates an additional alligator noise that is combined with the default billowy noise. Use the
folder to control the vertical blending of this noise.
Controls how much the alligator noise will affect the default billowy noise.
Uniform scale of elements in the noise.
Per Component button for separate scales along each axis.
Per Component button, this lets you scale the
Offset within the evaluated noise field (added to each axis). If you have the general noise effect you want, but want to get a different set of values for a different look, try changing the offset.

will darken the noise, increasing the range of values in originally bright areas.

will stretch out the range of values for originally dark areas, which will increase the overall brightness of the noise.

The number of iterations of distortion to add to the output of the basic noise. The more iterations you add, the more

the output. Note that the output may have fewer octaves than this parameter (that is, increasing the parameter will eventually stop adding detail), because the node eventually stops when there’s no more room to add more detail in the output.
The frequency increment between iterations of fractal noise added to the basic output. Note that you can use a negative value.
The scale increment between iterations of fractal noise added to the basic output. The higher the value the larger the
added to the output. You can use a negative value for roughness.

This ramp lets you control the strength of the alligator noise function across the vertical profile of the skybox.
    The horizontal axis represents the vertical height (minimum on the left, maximum on the right). The vertical axis represents the strength of output when the noise function generates that point within the range.
Generates wispy noise inside the Sky Box to create more broken-up cloud shapes.
Generates a fine, feather like wispy noise that can be combined or overwritten by the default billowy noise. Use the controls inside the
folder to change the blending with the billowy noise.
Controls the strength of the wispy noise. Larger values create finer and more broken up shapes, while lower values create smoother wispy details.
Per Component button for separate amplitudes along each axis.
Per Component button, this lets you scale the
Uniform scale of elements in the noise.
Per Component button for separate scales along each axis.
Per Component button, this lets you scale the
Offset within the evaluated noise field (added to each axis). If you have the general noise effect you want, but want to get a different set of values for a different look, try changing the offset.
You can animate the noise using an expression such as
here. This is faster to compute than
, but gives the visual effect of
across the noise field, which may or may not be acceptable.
Per Component button for separate additional offsets along each axis.
Per Component button, this lets you add the a separate offset along each axis.
When enabled, a turbulence noise is generated to displace the default wispy noise to create additional finer wispy details.
The type of noise to generate. Different algorithms give noise with different characteristics.
The default. A faster and more interesting variant of Perlin noise.
Sparse Convolution noise is similar to Worley noise. Does not have artifacts at grid points.
Produces a bumpy output. Named for its alleged resemblance to alligator skin.
A noise where the visual details are the same size.
A noise that’s stable over time, like a rotated Perlin noise, useful to create noise that seems to swirl and flow smoothly across time. Use the
parameter below to control the rotation.
A noise similar to Perlin but the noise lattice is on a tetrahedral mesh rather than a grid.  This can avoid the grid patterns often visible in Perlin noise.
Produces cellular features similar to plant cells, ocean waves, honeycombs, cratered landscapes, and so on.
A variant of Worley noise that produces blunted and cornered features.
A variant of Worley F1 noise that uses Manhattan distance calculation. Useful when you want unusual-looking noise.
A variant of Worley F2-F1 noise that uses Manhattan distance calculation. Useful when you want unusual-looking noise.
A variant of Worley F1 noise that uses Chebyshev distance calculation. Useful when you want unusual-looking noise.
A variant of Worley F2-F1 noise that uses Chebyshev distance calculation. Useful when you want unusual-looking noise.
Generates perlin noise based cloud pattern influenced by the
Generates simplex noise based cloud pattern influenced by the
parameter. Simplex noise similar to Perlin, but the noise lattice is on a tetrahedral mesh rather than a grid.  This can avoid the grid patterns often visible in Perlin noise.
Generates fast simplex noise based cloud pattern influenced by the
parameter. This simplex noise function uses a different lattice structure and a cheaper accumulation method.
Controls the strength of the turbulent noise. Larger values create finer and more broken up shapes, while lower values create smoother wispy details.
Per Component button for separate amplitudes along each axis.
Per Component button, this lets you scale the
Flattens the noise to prevent extreme spikes by damping the values. Higher values create a smoother look.
Controls the overall gamma of the generated noise. Values less than

will darken the noise, increasing the range of values in originally bright areas.
    Conversely, values greater than
will stretch out the range of values for originally dark areas, which will increase the overall brightness of the noise.
This value expands or shrinks the overall range of tonal values. Particularly, each noise value is pushed towards (if

the output. Note that the output may have fewer octaves than this parameter (that is, increasing the parameter will eventually stop adding detail), because the node eventually stops when there’s no more room to add more detail in the output.
The frequency increment between iterations of fractal noise added to the basic output. Note that you can use a negative value.
The scale increment between iterations of fractal noise added to the basic output. The higher the value the larger the
added to the output. You can use a negative value for roughness.
Controls how much the noise is distorted in the direction of decreasing noise values if
, and in the direction of increasing noise values if
. When worley details are added to the noise pattern, the effect of distortion are largely diminished.
How much to stretch the noise in each direction. The advantage of using this instead of
is that it preserves some details unstretched, making the stretched noise pattern more natural looking.
Warps the generated noise such that the noise pattern is bending or hanging towards the given droop direction.
Noise pattern without (left) and with droop applied (right):
The direction in which the noise is warped.
Masks the wispy noise based on the density of the default billowy noise using a threshold range.

control the masking range.
    By default, where the billowy noise density is at the minimum and maximum of this range, the wispy strength multiplier is

, respectively. Wispy noise is reduced in areas where the mask value is smaller.
    Set this value to
to fill the skybox with wispy noise.
Controls the range of values used for masking the wispy noise in conjunction with
. The effective range of mask values is from

This ramp lets you control the strength of the wispy noise function across the vertical profile of the skybox.
    The horizontal axis represents the vertical height (minimum on the left, maximum on the right). The vertical axis represents the strength of output when the noise function generates that point within the range.
Vary the generated noise with time. This controls the rate of change of the noise pattern.
The time at which to evaluate the cloud noise.
When turned on, offsets the evaluated noise patterns that gives the visual effect of
across the noise field simulating a wind like effect.
Controls how fast the noise pattern movies in the direction given by
The direction that is used to offset the noise pattern.
When turned on, this controls how much the direction (given by
) will blend towards the Y-axis. Use this control to add a small amount of upwards motion to the direction.
Controls the offset difference between the bottom and the top of the skybox.

) the density output by the skybox is also reduced.
    When this is turned on, the density range will more closely match the
When the checkbox is on, clamp density values so they are never greater than this value.
Multiplies the density using this value in the regions where billowy noise is generated.

Multiplies the density using this value in the regions where the wispy noise is generated.
    Generally, wispy noise is more opaque than a filled billowy cloud.
Turn this on to shape the output of the density with a ramp.

is on, this ramp lets you control the density output. The horizontal axis represents the input density range (minimum on the left, maximum on the right). The vertical axis represents the number to output when the density value is at that point within the range.
Turn this on to shape the output of the density along the vertical profile of the skybox.

This ramp lets you control the output density across the vertical profile of the skybox.
    The horizontal axis represents the vertical height (minimum on the left, maximum on the right). The vertical axis represents the density scale to output when the noise function generates that point within the range.

Deactivates any voxels that have the background value. This is useful for cleaning up the result of an operation that may have speculatively activated a large band of voxels, but may not have placed non-background values in all of them.
For example, you may have a
turned on to ensure you have room to displace the volume. Then you can use one with
to free up the voxels you didn’t need to use.
Computes the minimum and maximum values of the density volume given by
The name of the volume to be used as density for the cloud box. Usually you should leave it as

title: Sky Box
summary: Creates a volume filled with volumetric clouds.
